title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
This post highlights a data science project analyzing the real-world impacts of decentralized renewable energy (DRE) technologies in India. Leveraging user-level evidence collected by the Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW), I explored how DRE access varied across gender and states ‚Äî and how it related to reported changes in household income.
The analysis aimed to answer: Who is using DRE? and What are the livelihood outcomes? I used R to clean, visualize, and interpret the data, with a focus on two questions: 1. Do women benefit differently from DRE access? 2. How does adoption differ by technology and state?

title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
This post highlights a data science project analyzing the real-world impacts of decentralized renewable energy (DRE) technologies in India. Leveraging user-level evidence collected by the Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW), I explored how DRE access varied across gender and states ‚Äî and how it related to reported changes in household income.
The analysis aimed to answer: Who is using DRE? and What are the livelihood outcomes? I used R to clean, visualize, and interpret the data, with a focus on two questions: 1. Do women benefit differently from DRE access? 2. How does adoption differ by technology and state?

title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
üìä Visualization 1: Income Change by Gender
# Load ggplot2
library(ggplot2)

# Stacked bar chart - income change by gender
ggplot(gender_data, aes(x = Gender, fill = IncomeChange)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill") +
  labs(
    title = "Reported Income Change by Gender",
    x = "Gender",
    y = "Percentage of Users",
    fill = "Income Change"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent)

Interpretation: The vast majority of users ‚Äî regardless of gender ‚Äî reported increased income from DRE adoption. Interestingly, women were slightly more likely than men to report financial gain, suggesting DRE may help narrow gender income gaps in rural areas.

title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
üìä Visualization 2: Technology Type by State
# Horizontal bar chart - DRE tech by state

ggplot(state_data, aes(x = State, fill = Technology)) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge") +
  labs(
    title = "DRE Technology Adoption by State",
    x = "State",
    y = "Number of Users",
    fill = "Technology"
  ) +
  coord_flip()

Interpretation: This plot shows that different states have adopted different DRE solutions. Uttar Pradesh leads in solar refrigerator use, while Odisha has widespread adoption of solar pumps. These trends could reflect regional policy support, agriculture needs, and program implementation models.

title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
üí° Takeaways

DRE is working: Most users reported increased income post-adoption, reinforcing the link between clean energy and livelihoods.
Women benefit too: Female users reported slightly higher income benefits, making a case for scaling gender-inclusive DRE programs.
Customization matters: Adoption patterns vary by region and technology ‚Äî one-size-fits-all programs may miss local needs.

title: Analyzing Decentralized Renewable Energy Impacts
text:
üìÅ Notes

Data Source: CEEW‚Äôs Powering Livelihoods initiative
Tools Used: R, ggplot2, dplyr
Project Type: Exploratory Data Analysis, Policy-Relevant Visualization

title: Can Microgrids Power the Global South?
text: üìÑ View Full PDF

title: Can Microgrids Power the Global South?
text:
Introduction
In the Global South, millions still lack access to electricity. Extending central grids is often not feasible due to terrain, cost, or infrastructure gaps. Microgrids ‚Äî decentralized, often solar-powered systems ‚Äî provide a clean, scalable alternative. This blog post draws from a Q&A-style analysis conducted for ES 145, highlighting microgrids‚Äô role in alleviating energy poverty and mitigating climate change.

title: Can Microgrids Power the Global South?
text:
Key Takeaways

Microgrids last 7‚Äì10+ years, with periodic battery replacement being the biggest cost.
Case studies from India, Nepal, and West Africa show large-scale viability.
Solar microgrids emit 95% less CO‚ÇÇ than diesel-based systems.
Microgrids improve rural incomes, job access, and women‚Äôs empowerment.
The levelized cost of energy (LCOE) is cheaper for solar microgrids than diesel.
Please view attached pdf for figures!

title: Can Microgrids Power the Global South?
text:
Final Thoughts
Microgrids are not just an interim solution ‚Äî they‚Äôre a cornerstone for energy justice, sustainability, and resilience in the Global South. Backed by supportive policy, local ownership, and sustainable financing, they can align access and mitigation goals for 2030 and beyond.

title: About Me
text:
I grew up between India and the Bay Area ‚Äî and that cross-cultural experience shaped how I see people, place, and the planet.
It taught me that environmentalism is deeply personal and often rooted in how we connect to community and place.
Travel has been a huge part of my life ‚Äî from Kerala‚Äôs backwaters to Santa Barbara‚Äôs coastline, I‚Äôve found meaning in motion. Whether it‚Äôs through cultural festivals or street food, I love learning about the world through lived experiences.

title: About Me
text:
üíÉ Dance and Movement
I have always been the type to never sit still. I grew up playing Table Tennis, Soccer and Water Polo. In college I joined UCSB Taara - a nationally competitive bollywood fusion dance team. This has been a great way to connect with my culture while also finding value in movement. I also love working out in particular Yoga Sculpts and hope to become an instructor one day!

title: About Me
text:
üåä Marine Life & SCUBA
Becoming a certified diver opened my eyes to the fragility of marine ecosystems.
Having now completed over 50 dives, they have helped deepen my commitment to protecting coral reef and island ecosystems.
